    Best controller with the best response times.

    |
    |
    Posted 1 year ago. Owned for 3 weeks when reviewed.
    This reviewer received promo considerations or sweepstakes entry for writing a review.

    I have used various other controllers to include the Elite 1, Elite 2 and Scuff. This controller beats them all without any doubt! This controller has the best response times i have ever witnessed in a cobtroller and its especially noticible playing games like For Honor where response times really matter. I have not had any stick drift issues once so ever, if you do get stick drift you just have to recalibrate them from the controllers menu. From the menu you can also customise lighting and many other features like remapping the back buttons, setting response of the analog sticks and triggers and even see your notifications from your phone. The original controller i bought at launch had an issue with its A button, I contacted Turtle Beach's customer support and they responded next day and had a new controller shipped free of charge that same day without any hastle. Between the hardware and the support Tuetle Beach has would definitely recomwnd this controller!

    I would recommend this to a friend

  • Rated 5 out of 5 stars

    Great Controller, Lots of Ultra, not much stealth

    |
    |
    Posted 3 weeks ago. Owned for 3 weeks when reviewed.
    This reviewer received promo considerations or sweepstakes entry for writing a review.

    There is a lot to say about this controller. I go through controllers like bear goes through honey jars... I have had 4 of these controllers so far. None of them have had any stick drift after a year of use. The ones I have returned were due to some of the perceived lack of QA in the early batches that were shipped out. In all cases of returns it was the shoulder buttons that would start to have issues. My current one doesn't have any of these issues. Issues: I have read other reviews about the anti-friction rings on these controllers wearing grooves into the sticks, I have not seen this and as I said I have had one in constant use for over a year. The only negative I really have for this controller is the placement of the menu buttons. The Menu/Start/Select/Whatever you call them now, button on the left side of the controller is too close to the stick. You have to really concentrate to get your finger around the stick to hit the button. But that doesn't cause issues in any of the games I play, but it may for some people. Comfort: The controller itself is very comfortable in the hand. It has a slight texture to the grips that keep it comfortably in your palm. The buttons are all responsive, though if you are used to Scuf you may feel that they are a bit "squishy" compared to the faced buttons of the Scuf. I tend to use my Stealth Ultra for Shooters and even rocket league. I also have a couple of Scuf Instinct controllers, as well as the newer Scuf Valor Pro Wired Controller which I also love. The stealth ultra is a very comfortable controller. The placement of the back buttons works perfect for my hands. I'll post some images of how my hand sits on them for reference. Performance: I tend to use my controllers in a wired scenario, though I have used this particular controller wireless many times using the included dongle. I keep the dongle in the charging cradle that came with the controller. The only downside to using it wireless is that there is a delay when you want to start your Xbox from a shot down state. Sometimes the dongle doesn't connect for up to a minute meaning the Xbox just sits there until. the dongle finally connects and sends the startup signal. Like I said, I tend to use it wired so I don't run into that issue. I don't notice any lag above what I would expect from a wireless Xbox controller when in wireless mode. The sticks themselves have a great feel and the built-in response curves of the sticks just feel right to me. That is one of the reasons I prefer this over my Scuf controllers for games like Call of Duty. The aim just feels better. There are multiple curves you can choose from in the settings. I tend to stick to the Precision setting, and I set all my dead zones to 0%. It feels great and the aim is super responsive. The triggers are also very nice and the only thing I would change on them would be to make the trigger locks put the triggers into more of a mouse click feel instead of the current slightly squishier feel. There is not much travel, but compared to the mouse click, style trigger locks on my Scuf it just feels a bit soft. This doesn't affect my game play, but it is strictly a preference thing. The placement of the rear buttons is fine, I don't really have any pros or cons vs. other controllers. As with any controller the back buttons and their useability really hinges on how your hand lays on them and how easy they are for you to hit, without accidently hitting them. If they are awkward to you after a week of using it, you may want to try something else because if you can't feel comfortable with your back buttons, you will not get good muscle memory and will have to mentally stop to think about what you are doing when trying to hit them and that isn't good for any controller. So I highly recommend trying them out and also trying out some other controllers. Back buttons are not a deal breaker for some people, but if you do plan to use them, make sure you give it a good week of daily use to really see if they work for your hand size and shape and the way you hold your controller. Software: The software for the controller is fine for the most part, the issue I tend to have is that saving the settings back to the controller profile is not as simple as it should be. It can be confusing and is it feels like there were too many steps added. As you will see in the images, There are two menus that represent the memory profiles in the software and the onboard memory profiles. They do not always match up. And you would assume that you can just click the one you are adjusting in the software and then just match it up with the one you want to save it to on the controller, but you end up having to open another menu which makes it even more confusing. So the software could definitely use some more focus on UI/UX (I may be biased as I have been a software engineer and architect for over 25 years). The lighting is fairly straight forward though the colors do have some apparently duplication, and are rather limited. I would like the option to set custom colors for some of the effects but most of them have pre-set color choices. Not a deal breaker, but should be something that is easy to add more options too. Most of these settings can also be done directly on the screen built into the controller as well which is a nice bonus. I have not used any of the app control buttons to tie it in with phone or social media apps, I just don't need that on my controller. Summary: I am very happy with this controller, and like I said I have a lot of controllers and tend to go through them pretty fast. I currently have 1 Stealth Ultra that I use on my personal Xbox and PC in my office. I also have a Scuf Valor Pro in my office for when I just need a change. I have 3 Scuf Instinct Pro controllers, which I do enjoy, but the Stealth Ultra just feels better in game. I wish it had the trigger stops of the Scuf controllers, but that doesn't hold it back at all. I also have a few Xbox Elite controllers lying around, an old Razer Wolverine Pro, and have returned most other controllers (Nacon, Rig, Thrustmaster, etc...) My currently main daily drivers are the Stealth Ultra and the Various Scuf controllers depending on what I am playing and on which one of the Xboxes I happen to be playing on in a given day. We have a family of 4 who are all Xbox and PC, so when we play together as a family or have friends over we have plenty of options for controllers. I highly recommend this controller, especially if you play FPS games and need good aim. But like I said, test it out, see how it feels to you. I am a BestBuy Total Member, so I get an auto 24 month replacement plan on everything. So no harm in trying things out to find what works.

    I would recommend this to a friend

    Software

    Rated 3 out of 5 stars

    Could have been amazing. One major design flaw.

    |
    |
    Posted 1 year ago. Owned for less than 1 week when reviewed.
    This reviewer received promo considerations or sweepstakes entry for writing a review.

    This controller seemed great at first minus the extremely buggy software both on Android and Xbox. Although the software was a bit of a pain to get working, once it was setup it seemed to be a decent controller. Aiming feels a bit different coming from a Scuf Controller but that might be due to the controller using different response curves. Im sure with enough time, one can used to it. The biggest flaw has to do with the hardware. The anti friction rings that are supposed to make the thumb sticks glide nice and smooth when pushed all the way to the edge are not soft enough and after only a few hours of gameplay, the plastic on the thumb stick (left one on particular) have gouges in them from rubbing on the anti friction rings. They have actually done the exact opposite of what they were meant to do. Now, because the plastic has been scratched the thumb sticks do not glide smoothly at all. They feel like they are grinding when you rotate the stick. This is obviously something they wont be able to remedy with a software update and will probably end up having to recall all of the controllers they've sold until they can get this hardware redesigned and remade. I really wanted to love this controller, especially for its Hall Effect thumb sticks, but this just isnt it. I will be returning mine and hopefully Turtle Beach will get this figured out for a future iteration, but for now, I would stay away.

    No, I would not recommend this to a friend

    Rated 1 out of 5 stars

    So much hope, so little reward.

    |
    |
    Posted 1 year ago. Owned for 3 weeks when reviewed.
    This reviewer received promo considerations or sweepstakes entry for writing a review.

    As an avid gamer who is always trying new controllers, I had high hopes for this one. The clicky buttons and hall effect sticks were a major draw for me. I wish someone would create a basic controller with good sticks and clicky buttons. But after opening the box, I was greeted with beautiful hardware and a carrying case that had a soft, suede-like interior, unlike the elite controllers. The controller feels great in my hand, and most of the buttons are a joy to click. However, my initial excitement was short-lived, as I was extremely disappointed with the following issues: random power downs mid-use (every few minutes), random disconnections (which required me to repair every few minutes), inability to pair with the mobile app (preventing me from updating it, even after trying on multiple devices), right trigger with a strange click as if there was debris stuck inside not allowing a full click, and left stick not calibrated properly and, even after following the on-device recalibration, it would only input right and down (I have a video of this happening). Moreover, any changes made to settings such as color and rear buttons would only save until the controller turned off, after which it would factory reset itself. I couldn't recommend this controller to anyone. Thank you, Turtle Beach, for trying something new and pushing others to compete, but unfortunately, the only way I'd keep this controller is if it was free. I have returned the device and will continue to search for a controller that actually works and impresses. Thanks for reading my review.

    No, I would not recommend this to a friend

    So many things to love, but so many let downs. I’ve been trying for years to find the perfect controller. I really thought this might be it. However I bought this controller less than two weeks ago and have maybe 50+ hrs on it. I don’t like that not all of the buttons are remappable. You cannot remap the start select or capture buttons. The controller feels lighter than other pro controllers which is really nice. But I can tell you that the battery life is an exaggeration. If I leave it full power mode it lasts me the day. However my biggest gripe is the thumb sticks. No way to change heights and the thumb sticks grind against the terrible friction ring. I’m going to have to return the controller because the gritty grind feeling that is ruining my game play. I constantly feel the thumbsticks grinding which pulls me from game experience. This could have been a really great control. But it’s ok as is. The thumbsticks make the a really nice pro controller sub par experience. I really wanted to love this product. I do not see how this made it through QC.
